Now, we're going to talk about something that really hits us where we live - the way we eat.
You've probably noticed that food - how it's prepared and where it comes from and even how it is grown or raised - has become a serious issue.
And that is due, in no small part, to Mark Bittman.
In cookbooks, newspaper columns and online videos, Mark Bittman has become a national advocate for simple, healthful, environmentally responsible food.

His biggest platform might have been his regular opinion column for The New York Times where, for the past five years, he's written about everything from higher wages for food workers to improving the U.S.
school lunch program.
In September, though, Bittman announced that he is putting down his pen, if not his fork, to join a California food startup, and we wanted to talk to him about that.
Mark Bittman joins us now.
Welcome, thanks for joining us.
Really happy to be here and quite flattered.
Thank you.
Well, thank you.
And I'm going to start by asking - why did you become a food writer?
I actually - this goes back 35 years - I started cooking when I was in college and worked for a community newspaper for a long time.
And then, when I decided to try to make a living writing, no one was interested in anything I wrote about, until I started writing about food.
That's the truth.
How did you then incorporate your interest in things like sustainable agriculture and public health?
It sounds to me like you were actually always interested in those issues, you just didn't have a vehicle for writing about it.
Well, that's kind of right.
I was always interested in let's say progressive issues, but it did take me a long time to see how food fit into the big picture.
And I think it started to become more obvious to me in the late '90s, early 2000s.
And I saw that the sort of standard American diet was nutritionally problematic and that it was unfair in many ways and that the food system was flawed in many ways.
And as those thoughts started to gel and come together, I thought, well, I should write about this stuff.
And who better to write about it for than The Times?
You know, you're clear on the column and you make it a point to say that you are not the only person who had these insights.

Do you remember what it is that unlocked this for you?

A couple of things happened - one is that I became middle-aged or maybe even late middle-aged.
And it was clear that not paying attention to how and what I ate was having a personal impact.
But the other was that there was a U.N.
report called ""Livestock's Long Shadow,"" which identified industrial production of livestock as one of the major contributors to greenhouse gas production and global warming.
And that gave me pause.
That made me think, I need to go in this other direction - this is really important, this is a calling, in a way.
This is a place where agriculture and nutrition, diet, health and so on, all come together.

I'm just curious, what's your take on why that is?
We have created an environment that encourages the consumption of bad food.

So you're swimming in that environment and as, you know, the fish is unaware of the water, we're unaware of the fact that everywhere we go, we are encouraged to eat junk food and industrially raised food and industrially raised animal products and so on.
